Description: Small mould-made scarab Egyptian blue; back with some modelling for head and clypeus, and simple incised divisions in single line for prothorax and elytra; at side, legs simply modelled, with undercut triangle; underside crudely incised with a walking quadruped (possibly a bull or less likely a lion?) with an element (lotus flower or hieroglyphic sign?) in front of its forelegs; very eroded.
Curator's comments: Found unregistered, but with other objects from Naukratis with EEF labels from Petrie's excavations at Naukratis in 1885.

The same box, however, provided an element from Kamiros (2013,5012.7). The motif displayed on the underside of the scarab is not attested on the usual scarabs and scaraboids produced at the Scarab Factory (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Therefore, its findspot should be considered with extreme caution. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.24) (phase 3)
